result.markdown:
--- title: "4 Data Wrangling and Manipulation" code-copy: true code-line-numbers: true tidy: true code-annotations: below --- # 4.1 PART I ## Learning objectives - Understand DataFrames - Manipulate, transform and analyse DataFrames ## 4.1.1 Introduction Dataframes, as we saw [the previous section](week-2.qmd), is a tabular data format, with columns and rows. Columns are *variable* names and rows are individual *observations*. Just like other data structures dicussed in previous chapters, a DataFrame handles different data types: - int64: whole numbers (e.g age = 30) - float64; numbers with decimals (e.g. height = 1.9, temperature = 33.0) - datetime64: date and time - category: catogories or factors (e.g. gender = male, female; race = black, white, ...) - bool: True or False - object: string According to Hadley Wickman, a DataFrame should be in a *tidy* format: > 1. Each variable is a column; each column is a variable. > 2. Each observation is row; each row is an observation. > 3. Each value is a cell; each cell is a single value. The pandas package provide a toolbox of working analysing, querying and transforming DataFrames. We will continue working with the `gapminder dataset. First load pandas and read the data, saving it as "gapminder": ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd gapminder = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/aubreympungose/data-science-course/main/weeks/data/gapminder.csv") ``` ::: Let's examine the data by looking at few observations: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.332 9240934 820.853030
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962 31.997 10267083 853.100710
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.020 11537966 836.197138
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.088 13079460 739.981106
``` ::: ::: You can check how many variables are in the data and what type of data: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 1704 entries, 0 to 1703 Data columns (total 6 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 country 1704 non-null object 1 continent 1704 non-null object 2 year 1704 non-null int64 3 lifeExp 1704 non-null float64 4 pop 1704 non-null int64 5 gdpPercap 1704 non-null float64 dtypes: float64(2), int64(2), object(2) memory usage: 80.0+ KB ``` ::: ::: You can see that `gapminder` has 6 columns and 1704 rows. The columns in the dataset are: - country: Simply the country - continent: Continent - year: The year data was collected - lifeExp: Life expectancy of a country in year - pop: Population of the country in a year - gdpPercap: Gross Domestic Product of a country in a year You can also print the columns in the dataset by using `.columns` attribute. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.columns ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` Index(['country', 'continent', 'year', 'lifeExp', 'pop', 'gdpPercap'], dtype='object') ``` ::: ::: You can get the number of rows by using `.index` attribute: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.index ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` RangeIndex(start=0, stop=1704, step=1) ``` ::: ::: ## MANIPULATING COLUMNS #### Access/Select columns We may be interested in some of the columns in the `gampminder` dataframe, let say, for example, "country" only. You can select a specific column by taking the name of the DataFrame, followed by square brackets (`[]`) and passing the name of the "column" inside square brackets: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder["country"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` 0 Afghanistan 1 Afghanistan 2 Afghanistan 3 Afghanistan 4 Afghanistan ... 1699 Zimbabwe 1700 Zimbabwe 1701 Zimbabwe 1702 Zimbabwe 1703 Zimbabwe Name: country, Length: 1704, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: To Access multiple, columns you follow the same method as above, except that you wrap column names list (`[]`), so you end up with double sqaure brackets. Let's say we want to select "country", "pop", and "year" columns: ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder[["country", "pop", "year"]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
country pop year
0 Afghanistan 8425333 1952
1 Afghanistan 9240934 1957
2 Afghanistan 10267083 1962
3 Afghanistan 11537966 1967
4 Afghanistan 13079460 1972
... ... ... ...
1699 Zimbabwe 9216418 1987
1700 Zimbabwe 10704340 1992
1701 Zimbabwe 11404948 1997
1702 Zimbabwe 11926563 2002
1703 Zimbabwe 12311143 2007

1704 rows × 3 columns

``` ::: ::: You can alse access columns by their index using `.iloc()` function. Remember that an index in Python starts at 0, for example, to access the first column ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.iloc[:, 0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` 0 Afghanistan 1 Afghanistan 2 Afghanistan 3 Afghanistan 4 Afghanistan ... 1699 Zimbabwe 1700 Zimbabwe 1701 Zimbabwe 1702 Zimbabwe 1703 Zimbabwe Name: country, Length: 1704, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: In the above code, the colon (`:`) specify that we want to retun all rows; you will more abouth this when selecting by both columns and rows. To access multiple columns, you pass a list of indexes of columns. For example, select the 1st, 3rd and 5th columns: ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.iloc[:, [0, 2, 4]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ```{=html}
country year pop
0 Afghanistan 1952 8425333
1 Afghanistan 1957 9240934
2 Afghanistan 1962 10267083
3 Afghanistan 1967 11537966
4 Afghanistan 1972 13079460
... ... ... ...
1699 Zimbabwe 1987 9216418
1700 Zimbabwe 1992 10704340
1701 Zimbabwe 1997 11404948
1702 Zimbabwe 2002 11926563
1703 Zimbabwe 2007 12311143

1704 rows × 3 columns

``` ::: ::: Suppose you want access a range of of columns, for example, from the 1st to the 3rd column: ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.iloc[:, 0:3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}
country continent year
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972
... ... ... ...
1699 Zimbabwe Africa 1987
1700 Zimbabwe Africa 1992
1701 Zimbabwe Africa 1997
1702 Zimbabwe Africa 2002
1703 Zimbabwe Africa 2007

1704 rows × 3 columns

``` ::: ::: ### Rename columns You may need to change column names. For example, in the `gapminder` dataset, we may change the "pop" column to population. You will use the `.rename()` function, pass the column argument, and specify column names within the dictionary (`{"old_name":"new_name"}`). We will assign the results to the new DataFrame named `gapminder_new`: ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder_new = gapminder.rename(columns = {"pop":"population"}) gapminder_new.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp population gdpPercap
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.332 9240934 820.853030
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962 31.997 10267083 853.100710
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.020 11537966 836.197138
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.088 13079460 739.981106
``` ::: ::: The "pop" column has been changed to "population". You can also rename multiple columns; in this case, rename "lifeExp" and "gdpPercap": ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder_new = gapminder.rename(columns = {"lifeExp":"life_expectancy", "gdpPercap":"gdp_pc"}) gapminder_new.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ```{=html}
country continent year life_expectancy pop gdp_pc
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.332 9240934 820.853030
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962 31.997 10267083 853.100710
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.020 11537966 836.197138
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.088 13079460 739.981106
``` ::: ::: ### Making new columns, Removing columns To create a new column you simply take the name of the dataframe, pass the string of the new columnn inside sqaure bracket, and assign values: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder["new_column"] = 20 gapminder.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap new_column
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314 20
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.332 9240934 820.853030 20
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962 31.997 10267083 853.100710 20
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.020 11537966 836.197138 20
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.088 13079460 739.981106 20
``` ::: ::: There is a new column added that has values of 20. In many cases, we may need to create a new column resulting from manipulating other columns. For example, we know that the GDP per capita is calculated from dividing the total GDP by a population. If we want to create a new column of the total GDP, we need to multiply GDP per capita by the population size of the country: ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder["total_gdp"] = gapminder["gdpPercap"] * gapminder["pop"] gapminder.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap new_column total_gdp
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314 20 6.567086e+09
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.332 9240934 820.853030 20 7.585449e+09
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962 31.997 10267083 853.100710 20 8.758856e+09
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.020 11537966 836.197138 20 9.648014e+09
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.088 13079460 739.981106 20 9.678553e+09
``` ::: ::: We have a new column ("total_gdp") added to the `gapminder` DataFrame. You can remove columns by using `.drop() function: ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder = gapminder.drop(["total_gdp", "new_column"], axis = 1) gapminder.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314
1 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.332 9240934 820.853030
2 Afghanistan Asia 1962 31.997 10267083 853.100710
3 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.020 11537966 836.197138
4 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.088 13079460 739.981106
``` ::: ::: ### Sort columns You can values b any column by using `.sort_values()` function: ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.sort_values(["lifeExp"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap
1292 Rwanda Africa 1992 23.599 7290203 737.068595
0 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.445314
552 Gambia Africa 1952 30.000 284320 485.230659
36 Angola Africa 1952 30.015 4232095 3520.610273
1344 Sierra Leone Africa 1952 30.331 2143249 879.787736
... ... ... ... ... ... ...
1487 Switzerland Europe 2007 81.701 7554661 37506.419070
695 Iceland Europe 2007 81.757 301931 36180.789190
802 Japan Asia 2002 82.000 127065841 28604.591900
671 Hong Kong, China Asia 2007 82.208 6980412 39724.978670
803 Japan Asia 2007 82.603 127467972 31656.068060

1704 rows × 6 columns

``` ::: ::: You can see that Rwanda had the lowest life expectancy. To sort values into descending order (highest to lowest), you pass `ascending = False`: ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} gapminder.sort_values(["pop"], ascending = False) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ```{=html}
country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap
299 China Asia 2007 72.961 1318683096 4959.114854
298 China Asia 2002 72.028 1280400000 3119.280896
297 China Asia 1997 70.426 1230075000 2289.234136
296 China Asia 1992 68.690 1164970000 1655.784158
707 India Asia 2007 64.698 1110396331 2452.210407
... ... ... ... ... ... ...
1299 Sao Tome and Principe Africa 1967 54.425 70787 1384.840593
1298 Sao Tome and Principe Africa 1962 51.893 65345 1071.551119
420 Djibouti Africa 1952 34.812 63149 2669.529475
1297 Sao Tome and Principe Africa 1957 48.945 61325 860.736903
1296 Sao Tome and Principe Africa 1952 46.471 60011 879.583586

1704 rows × 6 columns

``` ::: ::: You can see that China had the highest population. ## Manipulate Rows
